section.title: Windows applications on Linux
section.para: It is possible to run Windows applications under Xubuntu. A few possible choices are:

listitem.para: Wine, the Windows emulator. Wine allows running some Windows applications without having to install a Windows operating system. Refer to the Wine AppDB to find out which applications will run on Wine and the Wine documentation for FAQ's and user support.

VirtualBox, virtualization software. You can install a Windows operating system along with any application into a virtual machine managed by VirtualBox. Note that 3D support on VirtualBox is still quite unreliable. To read more about VirtualBox and virtualization, refer to the VirtualBox end-user documentation.

tip.para: Both Wine and VirtualBox are available in the software repositories.

section.title: Windows networking on Linux
section.para: Accessing Windows network shares under Xubuntu can be easily done using:

listitem.para: &file-manager;, with which you can browse publicly visible shares by clicking on the Network item in the sidebar. Alternatively, you can browse a remote file system by going to GoOpen Location... and entering smb://computername/sharename.
&gigolo;, which allows you to save bookmarks and manage remote file systems. To connect, click the first toolbar button. Select Windows Share from Service Type, then enter the remote share's details.

section.para: If some options are not available or do not work, ensure that the &package;gvfs-backends is installed.

section.title: Upgrading Xubuntu
section.para: A new version of Xubuntu is released every 6 months, a new LTS version is released every 2 years; the Software Updater should inform you when a new version of its type (LTS or non-LTS) is available for download.

For non-LTS versions there is only one way to upgrade from the previous version, LTS versions additionally offer an upgrade directly to the next LTS. For example a user of 14.10 can only upgrade to 15.04; a user of 14.04 could upgrade to 14.10 or 16.04.
Currently non-LTS versions are supported for 9 months and LTS versions for 3 years.

Upgrades usually take a while to complete. Typically, around 1000 megabytes of packages must be downloaded and installed, although the actual figure will depend on how many packages are already installed on your computer.

section.title: Upgrading to the next available release

listitem.para: Navigate to Software Sources, by clicking &wm-software-properties; and select the Updates tab
Select For any new version from the list labeled Notify me of a new Ubuntu version, enter your password, and press Close
Go to &wm-software-updater; and wait for the list of available updates to be downloaded
If a new version of Xubuntu is available, a box at the top of the window will appear saying that a new distribution release is available.
To upgrade to the next available release that you can upgrade to, save all of your open documents and press the Upgrade button in &wm-software-updater;

note.para: If you are not getting an upgrade notification, or aren't seeing the release you are expecting to upgrade to, see .

section.title: Changing your upgrade path
section.para: To change which releases you want to upgrade to, choose one of the following processes:

listitem.para: Navigate to &software-properties-usc; and select the Updates tab. In the Updates tab, select either For any new version or For long-term support versions from the Notify me of a new Ubuntu version dropdown depending on your choice.

Open the &terminal; and run sudoedit /etc/update-manager/release-upgrades and change the line starting with prompt= to prompt=normal (for all releases) or prompt=lts (for LTS releases) depending on your choice

note.para: If you are running a regular release that is not immediately followed by an LTS release, you should not change the upgrade target to LTS release.

caution.para: Upgrading an LTS version to anything other than another LTS version will lose the long term support.

section.title: Upgrading to the development version

warning.para: Development releases often suffer from package breakages and other problems. Only install a development release if you are prepared to attempt to fix these problems for yourself or if you want to help the Xubuntu team by testing and giving feedback.

note.para: You will need to be running the latest regular version to be able to upgrade to the version currently under development.

section.para: If you would like to install and test the latest development version of Xubuntu before it is released, run pkexec update-manager -c -d at the command line. This will allow you to upgrade to the current development release. Please consider getting involved with reporting usage of development versions and associated packages.
